title: What are the four common cognitive errors made by traders and how to avoid them?
first_phrase: This text delves into common cognitive errors that traders often make, leading to impulsive and irrational decision-making during active markets. The author highlights the importance of being present in these moments to avoid losing control, and identifies the four most frequent cognitive errors: causal inversion, contingency, analogy, and impossibility of the opposite. Additionally, the text discusses five frequent emotional reactions among traders, including fear and greed. The author emphasizes the value of humility and the willingness to continue learning, citing a study that shows experienced individuals often take greater risks. In the last 200 tokens, the author focuses on the first cognitive error and provides strategies to avoid it.

last_phrase: Remember to stay humble and always continue learning, as experience may not always be the best teacher. Cognitive errors can lead to faulty perceptions of reality, and traders can easily fall into the trap of overconfidence. Avoid classic cognitive errors, such as the "cause and effect" reversal, which can lead to potentially harmful decision-making. Just because you've succeeded once, doesn't mean you can stop evaluating each new decision with care.
